abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the West Bengal Forestry
            Project for India was satisfactory. The project achieved
            most of its objectives, institutional development was
            partially achieved, sustainability is uncertain at this
            time, and the performance of both the Bank and Borrower was
            satisfactory. Several lessons can be learned from this
            project. First, project design should be results oriented.
            Second, project design and implementation should focus more
            explicitly on measures to ensure sustainability. Third,
            communication both up and down implementing agency staff
            levels and responsible responses by staff reflecting
            understanding and accountability of their actions is
            essential for iterative identification and solving of
            problems, and other forms of adaptive management. Fourth,
            technical assistance contracts should be ready for signing
            as a condition of negotiations. Fifth, organizational reform
            is risky. Wide-reaching reorganization requires careful
            analysis of power structures and personality relationships
            and their potential impact on implementation. Finally,
            forest development planning and implementation should be
            site specific, and take into consideration technical
            expertise, environmental factors, views of local people, and
            market prospects.

abstracts.cdata!:
The West Bengal Forestry Project
            finances a 5-year program to comprise : (a) forestry works
            on about 290,000 ha, regenerating or afforesting degraded
            forest areas over 160,000 ha with multi-tier coverage under
            joint management arrangements with local populations; strip
            plantations on 5,000 ha; and expanding farm forest coverage
            by about 109,000 ha.; (b) supporting works including survey
            and demarcation of forest land, roads, small earthern dams,
            ponds, and wells; (c) special action programs geared to
            improve forestry research and plant propagation, train all
            forestry staff, support the joint management process through
            training and funding to NGOs, improve wildlife and protected
            areas management, afforest or rehabilitate about 28,000 ha
            of mangrove areas; (d) construction of buildings, purchase
            of vehicles and equipment, hiring of incremental staff and
            coverage of operating costs for the Forest Department (FD);
            and lastly, (e) fodder development in forest and non-forest
            areas  with the FD and the Animal Resources Development
            Department (ARDD).
